Headline: Building brands from the ground up!
Comment:
Rishabh Mariwala , your post on the patience required to build consumer brands in Indiaâ€”unlike the rapid scaling possible in techâ€”raises an important question: ğ——ğ—¼ğ—²ğ˜€ ğ˜ğ—µğ—² ğ˜ğ—¿ğ—®ğ—±ğ—¶ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—¼ğ—»ğ—®ğ—¹ ğ—©ğ—– ğ—ºğ—¼ğ—±ğ—²ğ—¹ ğ˜ğ—¿ğ˜‚ğ—¹ğ˜† ğ—®ğ—¹ğ—¶ğ—´ğ—» ğ˜„ğ—¶ğ˜ğ—µ ğ˜ğ—µğ—² ğ˜ğ—¿ğ—®ğ—·ğ—²ğ—°ğ˜ğ—¼ğ—¿ğ˜† ğ—¼ğ—³ ğ—°ğ—¼ğ—»ğ˜€ğ˜‚ğ—ºğ—²ğ—¿ ğ—¯ğ—¿ğ—®ğ—»ğ—±ğ˜€?Â Â 

As you  rightly pointed out - Tech startups scale fast, leveraging network effects & capital efficiency, making them ideal for venture-style returns. But in consumer brands, trust takes time. Distribution, word-of-mouth and habit formation donâ€™t happen overnight. The payoff is often significant but slowâ€”sometimes beyond the typical 7â€“10 year VC exit cycle.

So, is brand-building truly venture investible? Or does the return cycle required for VCs fundamentally mismatch the growth arc of a consumer brand?            

Would love to hear your perspective on navigating this intersection between capital velocity & brand-building patience.

It's fascinating to see how cultural nuances and consumer behavior deeply impact brand trust and loyalty.
